SEARCH
Module iu.util
Package edu.iu

Class IuSingleValue

java.lang.Object
edu.iu.IuSingleValue
public final class IuSingleValue extends Object
Provides consistent serialization, deserialization, and conversion behavior for single value types and sequences.

Identity Conversion

All values use identity conversion when the source value is an instance of the target type.

Strict Reversibility

Serialization must result in text that deserializes to a value equal to the original value.

Conversion to any type must result in a value that is equal to the original value when converted back to the original type.

Note that deserialization may lose precision or context; it is not required for serializing a deserialized value to result in the original serialized form.

Character Sequences

CharSequence uses identity conversion for both serialization and deserialization. Conversion to CharSequence is serialization; conversion from CharSequence to any other type is deserialization.

Character Streams

Reader is a viable deserialization source and serialization or conversion source value; it will be read fully when used in these scenarios. When used as a target type for deserialization or conversion, a StringReader wrapping all buffered content is returned.

Writer is a viable serialization target; all serialized text will be written, then flushed. When used as a target type for deserialization or conversion, a DetachedWriter wrapping all buffered content is returned. StringWriter or DetachedWriter may be used as source value for serialization or conversion.

Null Values

When serializing null to a CharSequence, null is returned. A null value must not be serialized to a Writer; applications requiring the ability to serialize a null value over a stream should should use a higher-level abstraction (i.e., JSON-B with null values enabled).

When converting or deserializing null from a CharSequence, null is returned. When deserializing from a Reader, null is only returned when the target type is Void or void and reading fully resulted in the empty string.

Primitive Values

The primitive types below are treated as equivalent, as may be used interchangeably via boxing and unboxing. When serializing from a primitive type, deserializing to a primitive type, or converting between primitive and non-primitive types, the boxed value is handled as parseable.

  • Character ~= char
  • Boolean ~= boolean
  • Integer ~= int
  • Long ~= long
  • Short ~= short
  • Byte ~= byte
  • Double ~= double
  • Float ~= float
  • Void ~= void (null only)

Conversion between primitive types may narrow precision but strict reversibility still applies: conversion must not result in value loss; converting back to the original type must result in the original value.

Parseable Values

The types listed are serialized using Object.toString() and deserialized as described:

  • String, with CharSequence.toString(); used first when String is needed for parsing serialized text
  • StringBuilder, with StringBuilder(CharSequence)
  • StringBuffer, with StringBuffer(CharSequence)
  • CharBuffer, with CharBuffer.wrap(CharSequence)
  • char[], with CharBuffer.wrap(CharSequence)
  • Character, with CharSequence.charAt(0), after verifying CharSequence.length() == 1
  • Boolean, Boolean.TRUE when case-insensitive equal one of the following to implicit true values; else Boolean.FALSE (unless null:
    • "true"
    • "Y"
    • "1"
    • "-1"
  • Number, with BigDecimal(String)
  • BigDecimal, with BigDecimal(String)
  • BigInteger, with BigInteger(String)
  • Integer, with Integer.parseInt(String)
  • Long, with Long.parseLong(String)
  • Short, with Short.parseShort(String)
  • Byte, with Byte.parseByte(String)
  • Double, with Double.parseDouble(String)
  • Float, with Float.parseFloat(String)
  • Void, by enforcing null
  • URL, with URL(String)
  • URI, with URI(String)
  • TimeZone, with TimeZone.getTimeZone(String)
  • Pattern, with Pattern.compile(String)
  • Enum, with Enum.valueOf(Class, String)

Binary Data

Binary data is serialized with Base64.getEncoder() and deserialized with Base64.getDecoder().

Binary data is converted to other types by first using String(byte[], String) with "UTF-8". Other types are converted to binary by converting to String then using String.getBytes(String) with "UTF-8".

Binary types are:

  • byte[]
  • ByteBuffer

Binary Streams

InputStream is a viable deserialization source via UTF-8 InputStreamReader, and serialization or conversion source value; it will be read fully when used in these scenarios. When used as a target type for deserialization or conversion, a ByteArrayInputStream wrapping all buffered content is returned.

OutputStream is a viable serialization target via UTF-8 OutputStreamWriter; all serialized data will be written, then flushed. When used as a target type for deserialization or conversion, a DetachedOutputStream wrapping all buffered data is returned. ByteArrayOutputStream or DetachedOutputStream may be used as source values for serialization or conversion.

Date/Time Values

Date/time values are serialized using ISO-8601, via Object.toString() from Temporal.

Date/time values are deserialized using DateTimeFormatter.parse(CharSequence) then converted to the target type:

  • Instant, with Instant.from(TemporalAccessor)
  • Year, with Year.from(TemporalAccessor)
  • YearMonth, with YearMonth.from(TemporalAccessor)
  • LocalDate, with LocalDate.from(TemporalAccessor)
  • LocalDateTime, with LocalDateTime.from(TemporalAccessor)
  • LocalTime, with LocalTime.from(TemporalAccessor)
  • ZonedDateTime, with ZonedDateTime.from(TemporalAccessor)
  • OffsetDateTime, with OffsetDateTime.from(TemporalAccessor)
  • OffsetTime, with OffsetTime.from(TemporalAccessor)

Date, Calendar, and Long

Date.toInstant() and Calendar.toInstant() are used to convert to Instant before serializing.

Date.from(Instant) is used to convert to Date after first deserializing as or converting to Instant.

Calendar.getInstance(), then Calendar.setTime(Date), is used to convert to Calendar after first deserializing as or converting to Date.

Long may be converted using Date(long), then converted to other date/time types. When serialized form is parseable as Long, it will be serialized first to Long then converted to Date before converting to other date/time types.

Relative Date/Time Values

Date/time values may be deserialized using the following ABNF grammar to designate a value relative to the current date/time. 

        relative = "now" [" " interval]
        interval = sign [" "] 1*DIGIT " " unit
        sign     = "+" / "-"
        unit     = TimeUnit / ChronoUnit

Single Value Sequences

Single value sequences may be

  • Serialized to RFC-4180 CSV Format
  • Deserialized from RFC-4180 CSV Format by passing one of the following Class values as target type.
    • Any array class with a single value component type, except for byte[] and char[]
    • IntStream
    • LongStream
    • DoubleStream
  • Deserialized from RFC-4180 CSV Format by passing ParameterizedType as target type, with one of the following classes as its raw type and a single value Class as its first actual type argument.
    • Iterable
    • Collection
    • Set
    • SortedSet
    • List
    • Queue
    • Deque
    • Stream
  • Converted between the single value sequence types listed above by converting each single value in the sequence.

Standards

This utility supports parseable and primitive type conversion scenarios described by JSON-B 3.0 Section 3: Default Mapping.

Non Requirements

This utility implements specific rules for converting between basic types from the java.base module. It is not intended as a flexible type conversion framework. No types other than those listed above are supported. In particular, conversion between Object, Map, and other complex data types is not implemented by this utility.

    • isSingleValue

      public static boolean isSingleValue(Class<?> type)
      Determines whether or not a Class represents a single value type.
      Parameters:
      type - class to check
      Returns:
      true if type is a single value type; else false

      Parameters:
      potentiallyPrimitiveClass - potentially primitive Class
      Returns:

      Gets the default value for an object or primitive type.
      Type Parameters:
      T - potentially primitive type
      Parameters:
      potentiallyPrimitiveClass - potentially primitive Class
      Returns:
      The value assigned to a field of the potentially primitive type when declared without an initializer; null unless the type is primitive.
